statement.p: True or false: \ds\diff{}{x}\{f(x)+g(x)\}=f'(x)+g'(x) when f and g are differentiable functions.

solution.p: True: this is exactly what the Sum Rule states.

statement.p: True or false: \ds\diff{}{x}\{f(x)g(x)\}=f'(x)g'(x) when f and g are differentiable functions.

solution.p: False, in general. The product rule tells us \diff{}{x}\{f(x)g(x)\}=f'(x)g(x)+f(x)g'(x). An easy example of why we can't do it the other way is to take f(x)=g(x)=x. Then the equation becomes \diff{}{x}\{x^2\}=(1)(1), which is false.

statement.p: True or false: \ds\diff{}{x}\left\{\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\right\}=\dfrac{f'(x)}{g(x)}-\dfrac{f(x)g'(x)}{g^2(x)} when f and g are differentiable functions.
Let f be a differentiable function. Use at least three different rules to differentiate g(x)=3f(x), and verify that they all give the same answer.

answer.p:
If you're creative, you can find lots of ways to differentiate!
Constant multiple: g'(x)=3f'(x).
Product rule: g'(x) = \diff{}{x}\{3\}f(x)+3f'(x)=0f(x)+3f'(x)=3f'(x).
Sum rule: g'(x)=\diff{}{x}\{f(x)+f(x)+f(x)\}=f'(x)+f'(x)+f'(x)=3f'(x).
Quotient rule: g'(x)=\diff{}{x}\left\{\frac{f(x)}{\frac{1}{3}}\right\}= \frac{\frac{1}{3}f'(x)-f(x)(0)}{\frac{1}{9}}=\frac{\frac{1}{3}f'(x)}{\frac{1}{9}}=9\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)f'(x)=3f'(x).
All rules give g'(x)=3f'(x).

solution.p:
If you're creative, you can find lots of ways to differentiate!
Constant multiple: g'(x)=3f'(x).
Product rule:
g'(x) = \diff{}{x}\{3\}f(x)+3f'(x)=0f(x)+3f'(x)=3f'(x)
Sum rule:
g'(x)\amp=\diff{}{x}\{f(x)+f(x)+f(x)\}=f'(x)+f'(x)+f'(x)
\amp=3f'(x)
Quotient rule:
g'(x)\amp=\diff{}{x}\left\{\frac{f(x)}{\frac{1}{3}}\right\}= \frac{\frac{1}{3}f'(x)-f(x)(0)}{\frac{1}{9}}=\frac{\frac{1}{3}f'(x)}{\frac{1}{9}}
\amp=9\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)f'(x) =3f'(x)
All rules give g'(x)=3f'(x).

hint.p: Use linearity and the known derivatives of x^2 and x^{1/2}.

solution.p:
We know, from Examples and in the CLP-1 text, that \diff{}{x}x^2=2x and \diff{}{x}x^{1/2}=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}. So, by linearity,
f'(x)=3\cdot 2x+ 4\cdot \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}=6x+\frac{2}{\sqrt{x}}

statement.p: Use the product rule to differentiate f(x)=(2x+5)(8\sqrt{x}-9x).

solution.p:
We have already seen \diff{}{x}\{\sqrt{x}\}=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}} in Example of the CLP-1 text. Now:
f'(x) &= (2)(8\sqrt{x}-9x)+(2x+5)\left(\frac{8}{2\sqrt{x}}-9\right)
&= 16\sqrt{x}-18x+(2x+5)\left(\frac{4}{\sqrt{x}}-9\right)
&=-36x+24\sqrt{x}+\frac{20}{\sqrt{x}}-45

statement.p: Find the equation of the tangent line to the graph of y=x^3 at x=\dfrac{1}{2}.

hint.p: The equation of a line can be determined using a point, and the slope. The derivative of x^3 can be found by writing x^3=(x)(x^2).

solution.p:
We already know that \diff{}{x}x=1 and \diff{}{x}x^2=2x, so we can compute the derivative of x^3 by writing x^3=(x)(x^2),
\diff{}{x} x^3 =\diff{}{x} (x)(x^2) = (1)(x^2)+(x)(2x)=3x^2
When this is evaluated at x=\frac{1}{2} we get \frac{3}{4}. Since we also compute \left( \frac{1}{2}\right)^3=\frac{1}{8}, the equation of the tangent line is
y - \frac{1}{8} = \frac{3}{4}\cdot \left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right).

statement.p:
A particle moves along the x--axis so that its position at time t is given by x=t^3-4t^2+1 .
At t=2, what is the particle's speed?
At t=2, in what direction is the particle moving?
At t=2, is the particle's speed increasing or decreasing?

hint.p: Be careful to distinguish between speed and velocity.

solution.p:
Let f(t)=t^3-4t^2+1. We saw in Question that \diff{}{t}t^3=3t^2. So
f'(t)&=3t^2-8t & f'(2)&=3\times 4-8\times 2=-4\cr f''(t)&=6t-8 & f''(2)&=6\times 2-8=4\cr
Hence at t=2, the particle has speed of magnitude {4}, and is moving {towards the left}. At t=2, f''(2) \gt 0, so f' is increasing, i.e. becoming less negative. Since f' is getting closer to zero, the magnitude of the speed is {decreasing}.

statement.p: Find the equation of the tangent line to the curve f(x)=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{x}+1} at the point \left(1,\frac{1}{2}\right).

hint.p: You know how to take the derivative of a reciprocal; this might be faster than using the quotient rule.

solution.p:
We need f'(1), so first we must find f'(x). Since f(x) is the reciprocal of \sqrt{x}+1, we can use the Corollary:
f'(x) = \dfrac{-\diff{}{x}\{\sqrt{x}+1\}}{(\sqrt{x}+1)^2}=\dfrac{-\frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}}{(\sqrt{x}+1)^2}= \dfrac{-1}{2\sqrt{x}(\sqrt{x}+1)^2}, so f'(1)=\dfrac{-1}{2\sqrt{1}(\sqrt{1}+1)^2}=\frac{-1}{8}.
Now, using the point \left(1,\frac{1}{2}\right) and the slope \frac{-1}{8}, our tangent line has equation y-\frac{1}{2}=-\frac{1}{8}(x-1).

statement.p: A town is founded in the year 2000. After t years, it has had b(t) births and d(t) deaths. Nobody enters or leaves the town except by birth or death (whoa). Give an expression for the rate the population of the town is growing.

hint.p: Population growth is rate of change of population.

solution.p: Population growth is rate of change of population. Population in year 2000+t is given by P(t)=P_0+b(t)-d(t), where P_0 is the initial population of the town. Then P'(t) is the expression we're looking for, and P'(t)=b'(t)-d'(t).

It is interesting to note that the initial population does not obviously show up in this calculation. It would probably affect b(t) and d(t), but if we know these we do not need to know P_0 to answer our question.

statement.p: Find all points on the curve y=3x^2 where the tangent line passes through (2,9).

solution.p:
We already know that \diff{}{x}x^2=2x. So the slope of y=3x^2 at x=a is 6a. The tangent line to y=3x^2 at x=a, y=3a^2 is y-3a^2=6a(x-a). This tangent line passes through (2,9) if
9-3a^2&=6a(2-a)
3a^2-12a+9&=0
a^2-4a+3&=0
(a-3)(a-1)&=0
\implies \;\; a&=1,3
The points are {(1,3),\ (3,27)}.

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \lim_{y\rightarrow 0}\left( \dfrac{\sqrt{100180+y}-\sqrt{100180}}{y}\right) by interpreting the limit as a derivative.

hint.p: Interpret it as a derivative that you know how to compute.

solution.p: This limit represents the derivative computed at x=100180 of the function f(x)=\sqrt{x}. Since the derivative of f(x) is \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}, then its value at x=100180 is exactly \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{100180}}.

statement.p: A rectangle is growing. At time t=0, it is a square with side length 1 metre. Its width increases at a constant rate of 2 metres per second, and its length increases at a constant rate of 5 metres per second. How fast is its area increasing at time t \gt 0?

hint.p: The answer is not 10 square metres per second.

solution.p: Let w(t) and l(t) be the width and length of the rectangle. Given in the problem is that w'(t)=2 and l'(t)=5. Since both functions have constant slopes, both must be lines. Their slopes are given, and their intercepts are w(0)=l(0)=1. So, w(t)=2t+1 and l(t)=5t+1.
The area of the rectangle is A(t)=w(t)\cdot l(t), so using the product rule, the rate at which the area is increasing is A'(t)=w'(t)l(t)+w(t)l'(t)=2(5t+1)+5(2t+1)=20t+7 square metres per second.

statement.p: Let f(x)=x^2g(x) for some differentiable function g(x). What is f'(0)?

hint.p: You don't need to know g(0) or g'(0).

solution.p: Using the product rule, f'(x)=(2x)g(x)+x^2g'(x), so f'(0)=0\cdot g(x)+0\cdot g'(x)=0. (Since g is differentiable, g' exists.)

statement.p: Verify that differentiating f(x)=\dfrac{g(x)}{h(x)} using the quotient rule gives the same answer as differentiating f(x)=\dfrac{g(x)}{k(x)}\cdot\dfrac{k(x)}{h(x)} using the product rule and the quotient rule.
